CuO nanocatalyst with layered structure was supported over Fe-exchanged zeolite-Y (CuO-Fe(III)-Y) for selective synthesis of amides by oxidative coupling of aromatic primary alcohols and amines. The CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst was characterized by different physicochemical and spectroscopic techniques. The amide bond formation reaction was found to occur in absence of any external base and reagents. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) study predicted the development of strong basic sites in the CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst that boosted the dehydrogenative coupling process. The activity of the material in such coupling reaction was found to be comparable to those of other costly metal catalysts under different reaction conditions. The product yield of the reaction was found to be substrate-dependent giving moderate to maximum yield of 85%. The anomalies in the reaction appeared in case of 5-nitro-2‑chloro-benzylalcohol that undergoes a CN coupling product through CCl bond activation. The mechanism of the reaction was believed to proceed through FeIV=O species that helped in the activation of the benzylic CH bond. Graphical abstract Synthesis of amides by oxidative coupling of alcohols and amines catalyzed by zeolite-Y supported Cu-Fe Catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CuO-nanoparticles Iron-exchanged zeolite-Y Benzyl alcohol Amines Amides Abbreviations CuO-NPs CuO-nanoparticles BA Benzyl alcohol Fe(III)-Y Iron-exchanged zeolite-Y 1 Introduction Copper (Cu) and iron (Fe) are the two low-cost metal and are of biological importance as they play a vital role in various metalloenzymes [1,2]. Different metal complexes of such metals are synthesized that can mimic the biosystem [3]. In this respect, zeolites that can provide similar electronic, confinement effect like that of the protein mantles have paved a new direction in the heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts known as zeozymes [4,5]. The metal complexes with a specific ligand environment or within the cages or framework do show good catalytic activity [6]. But the hard work involved in the synthesis and designing of suitable ligand system that can influence the activity of particular metal has pushed the researcher to think of ligand-free metal catalyst. Thanks to the introduction of nanoscience and nanotechnochnology that has substantially changed the direction in doing the catalytic reactions under ligand-free conditions using metal nanocatalysts [7,8]. Among the various metal nanocatalysts, the metal oxide nanoparticle of Cu either supported or unsupported appeared as a very active ligand-free nanocatalyst. They are widely used in different chemical transformation reactions including photochemical and also in wastewater management [9–11]. The copper oxide nanoparticle (CuONPs) of various dimensions and shapes has been studied by many other researchers for CC, CN bond formation, oxidation–reduction, and electrochemical reaction [9,11–14]. CuO-oxide alloyed, conjugated with different other metals are also found to show good activity in various catalytic reactions [15]. However, the controlled growth of CuONPs in the range of 10–20 nm is difficult due to their high tendency to get agglomerated [16,17]. To have control over the size of CuONPs different templating agents either soft or hard are employed [18]. Our own investigation on the synthesis of metal or metal oxide nanoparticles suggested that zeolite-Y can be a suitable hard matrix for the controlled growth of such nanoparticles [19]. Zeolite-Y also provides a good external surface to hold the metal nanoparticle, provides significant metal to surface interaction and thereby prevents from leaching [20]. Very recently it was found that the CuONPs supported on zeolite-Y appeared as an efficient solid catalyst for the mechanochemical synthesis of benzimidazole, benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, and Henry product [19]. In continuation to this work herein we tried to develop a layered CuO supported on Fe-exchange zeolite-Y for dehydrogenative amide synthesis reaction through alcohol and amine coupling. Amides are among the most essential compounds in chemistry and biology because of which the production of amide bonds (-CONH2-) through the dehydrogenative coupling of alcohol and amine has recently gained a lot of attention [21,22]. The dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols and amines to amides may fail as they encounter some undesired reactions like amine oxidation of amine to imines or nitriles and the aldehydes generated from alcohol may condense with amine [23,24]. Therefore, the controlled synthesis of amides with good yield without any undesired product is challenging. A number of synthetic approaches are so far adopted for the synthesis of various types of amides from different substrates such as acid chlorides, esters, carboxylic acids, aldehydes, alcohol coupling with amines and using oxime, nitriles, using different homogeneous, heterogeneous or nanocatalysts [25–33]. Gupta etal. synthesized amides from alcohol and N-substituted formamides by using Cu-Fe metal oxide catalyst [34]. Lakshmi Kantam and co-worker synthesized amides by carboxylic acids or aldehyde with dimethyl formamides using Cu-Fe hydrotalicite [35]. However, the reports on the synthesis of amides through dehydrogenative coupling of aromatic alcohols and amines using CuO nanocatalyst supported on Fe-exchange zeolite-Y under base free condition is very sparse in the literature [36]. Gabriel and his co-worker synthesized amide bond by direct oxidative amidation of N,N-dimethylanilines with anhydrides by using CuO on zeolite-Y [36]. Therefore, the present study reports for the synthesis of low-cost CuONP supported on Fe(III)-exchanged zeolite-Y material for such reaction in the absence of any other external base. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Sodium exchange zeolite-Y (Na-zeolite-Y) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The metal salts of cupric chloride dihydrate (CuCl2.2H2O) and anhydrous ferric chloride (FeCl3) were received from SRL. All the alcohols and amines were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. 70% tert‑Butyl hydroperoxide (tBuOOH) was obtained from HiMedia, Pvt, Ltd. All the solvents of HPLC grade used in the reaction and chromatographic separation were purchased from Merck. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe-exchange zeolite-Y For the synthesis of Iron (Fe) exchanged zeolite-Y (Fe (III)-Y), 2 g of sodium-Y(Na-Y) zeolite was suspended in an aqueous solution containing 0.01 M (0.032 g in 20 mL water) of anhydrous FeCl3. This solution was stirred at 60 ℃ under refluxing conditions for 24 h. The Fe (III)-Y was collected by simple filtration method using Whatman No 1 filter paper. The white solid material was washed with chlorine-free water for several times to remove the chloride (Cl − ) ions. The complete removal of chloride ions− was confirmed by the silver nitrate (AgNO3) test. From the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopic (ICP-OES) analysis the amount of Fe-loading was found to be 97 mg/L. 2.3 Synthesis and preparation of CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst Initially, the 1 g of Fe (III)-zeolite-Y was suspended in a 50 mL round bottom flask (RB) containing distilled water. Afterward, it was treated with a solution 20 mL 0.01 M (0.034 g in 20 mL water) CuCl2·2H2O separately. The Cu(II) solution was added dropwise followed by the slow addition of 1 M NaOH. After that whole solution mixture was refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h. The resultant solution was filtered using Whatman No 1 filter paper after 24 h of stirring, and the residue component was properly cleaned with deionized water by washing for multiple times. AgNO3 test revealed complete elimination of Cl− ion. The material was then dried under vacuum and the resultant material was grinded using mortar-pestle for 2 h. The fine light brown powdery material of CuO loaded Fe-exchanged zeolite-Y, CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. From the ICP-OES analysis found that the amount of Cu loading was ∼310 mg/L. 2.4 Procedure for dehydrogenative amide synthesis reaction via coupling of alcohol and amine The experiment was initially carried out by stirring 1 mmol each of alcohol and amine in 3 mL of CH3CN with 20 mg of catalyst in presence of 100 µL of 70% tBuOOH for 1 h at 60 °C. After 1 h of reaction added another 120 µL of tBuOOH solution under refluxing condition at the same temperature and stirred the reaction for another 3 h. The progress of the reaction was monitored by thin layered chromatography (TLC) (in different ratios of ethyl acetate, EtOAc, and n-hexane). After the completion, the product was extracted by addition of 20 mL EtOAc and 10 mL distilled H2O. The organic products were extracted from the solvent (EtOAc) using a rotary evaporator. The pure product was separated through the silica (60–120 mesh) column chromatography using EtOAc and n-hexane as eluent. The final products were characterized by 1H and 13C NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance) recorded in CDCl3(deuterated chloroform) solvent. The NMR spectra are provided in SI (Supporting Information). 2.5 Procedure for C-N coupling between aryl-halide and amine The reaction was performed by taking 1 mmol of both aryl halide and amine in 3 mL of CH3CN. To this 100 µL tBuOOH was added in presence of 20 mg of catalyst. After that reaction mixture was refluxed at 60 °C for 2 h under stirring. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC (EtOAc/n-hexane= 1:4). After completing the reaction process, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration. The reaction was workup by the addition of 20 mL of EtOAc and 10 mL of distilled water to the reaction mixture in a separating funnel. Then separated the organic layer and dried the organic mixture with sodium sulfate (Na2SO4). The desired pure product was separated through the silica (60–120 mesh) column chromatography using EtOAc and n-hexane as eluent. The 1H, 13C NMR of the desired products were recorded in CDCl3 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of the catalyst The synthesized catalyst CuO-Fe(III)-Y was characterized using different spectroscopic and electron microscopy analytical techniques and the findings are discussed below. The CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst was first characterized by Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis and the compound was found to be CuO supported on Fe exchange zeolite-Y. The PXRD pattern of CuO-Fe(III)-Y zeolite (red) almost resembled with the neat zeolite-Y (black), Fig. 1 a. Apart from this, peaks at 35.6° (−111) and 38.7° (111) in the XRD pattern revealed the presence of copper (II) oxide nanoparticles (CuO NPs), as shown in Fig. 1a,b (red) [37–39]. The average crystallite size of CuO-Fe(III)-Y was measured by Scherrer equation and found to be 199.24 nm [40]. The crystallite size was higher than of pristine zeolite-Y, 133.97 nm implying the loading of CuO nanoparticles. The oxidation state of Cu and Fe was evaluated from the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. The presence of Cu(II) species in the material was confirmed by the appearance of the prominent peak of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 at 933.1 and 953.8 eV, respectively (Fig. 2 a) [41–43]. The satellite peak characteristics of Cu(II) species were observed at 941.4 and 943.2 eV, indicating the formation of CuO. The existence of Fe (III) species in the synthesized material was revealed by the metal Fe (2p) XPS, (Fig. 2b). It exhibited two significant peaks for Fe 2p at 711.3 and 724.7 eV, respectively corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 [44,45]. In O 1 s spectrum peak at 529.6 eV confirmed the presence of metal oxide (M-O) species, Fig. 2c [46,47]. The XPS of Al 2p and Si 2p showed peaks at 74.1 and 102.5 eV, respectively corresponding to aluminosilicates, (Fig. S1a-b) [48]. Furthermore, the Si 2p spectrum showed a peak at 102.5 eV typical of SiO2, (Fig. S1a). The C 1s peak having a binding energy of 284.7 eV was used to fit all the XPS peaks, (Fig. S1c). In the Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum (Fig. 2d) the sharp signal in the low field region with g value ∼ 4.38 confirmed the presence of Fe (III) species in tetrahedrally or octahedrally distorted environment [49]. The EPR signals in the higher field region with g value at 2.29 was supposed to be contributed from the Cu (II) species [50]. The presence of broad signal with g value ∼2.86 was originated from Fe2O3 species [49]. The surface morphology of the material was characterized by FESEM (Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope). The formation of CuONPs was detected from TEM (Transmission Electron Microscope) analysis and the elemental analysis was done through EDX (Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy) analysis. The deposition of the layered CuO material over the Fe-exchange zeolite-Y was seen from the FESEM, (Fig. 3 a-c). TEM analysis revealed that the CuO was constituted of the fine CuONPs (Fig. 3d-f) having the dimension in the range of 11–16 nm as calculated from the particle size distribution analysis, Fig. 3g. The presence of Cu and Fe was further evaluated through EDX-analysis and the average weight% of Cu and Fe was estimated to be 21.2% and 7.2%, respectively (Fig. 4 a). The ratio of Cu: Fe (2.9:1) calculated from EDX analysis was matching with those obtained from ICP-OES analysis (3.2:1). The STEM-HADDF analysis also showed the presence of small CuONPs on Fe(III)-exchanged zeolite-Y crystallite, (Fig. 4b-e). The formation CuONPs was also evident from Raman analysis, (Fig. 5 a). The sharp signal at 503 and weak signal at 587 were for the Fe-zeolite framework and the peaks at around 300 cm−1 and 668 cm−1 were attributed to CuONPs [51]. The lattice vibrational band of CuO nanoparticles was observed below 200 cm−1. Other peaks at 587 cm−1 and 668 cm−1was for Fe-O and Fe-O-Fe vibrational bands [52]. The shifting in Raman band than those reported for CuO NP was due to the metal to support interaction and influence of zeolite framework [51]. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of synthesized material showed a peak at 1014 cm−1 due to asymmetric stretching [vas (Si-O-Si), vas (Si-O-Al)] as well as symmetric stretching vibrations at 727 cm−1 and 579 cm−1 vs (Si-O-Si) for bridge bonds. The peak at 463 cm−1 was assigned to bending vibrations of O-Si-O bond(Fig. 5b) [53]. The presence of such distinct vibrational bands indicated that the zeolite's overall framework was preserved even after CuO deposition in the surface. The surface area of the synthesized CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst was determined from Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, Fig. 5c. The surface area of CuO-Fe(III)-Y was found to be 432 m2/g. In comparison to that of the neat zeolite-Y (803 m2/g) the surface area was found to be less due to the blocking of the external pores by CuO surface that reduced the access to the N2 molecules [54]. In the ammonia (NH3)-TPD (Temperature Programmed Desorption) profile of CuO-Fe(III)-Y desorption peaks were observed at ∼305 °C, ∼347 °C, ∼391 °C signifying the presence of moderate acidic sites in the catalyst, Fig. 5d (blue curve). The TPD of the synthesized material was compared with the NH3-TPD of bared zeolite-Y, Fig. 5d (red curve). The neat zeolite-Y mostly showed three peaks at ∼202 °C, ∼240 °C, and ∼345 °C indicating the presence of both weak and moderate acidic sites. From NH3-TPD analysis it was observed that the weak acidic sites were modified after the incorporation of the CuO and Fe. While from the CO2-TPD graph, it was found that material contained both the weak and the strong basic sites as characterized by the desorption profile appearing at ∼204 °C and ∼428 °C, Fig. 5d (black curve). Usually, the zeolite-Y represents a broad spectrum in the range of 200–300 °C in the CO2-TPD profile [55]. The presence of a sharp desorption peak at higher temperature range ∼428 °C indicated for the creation of more stronger basic sites due to CuO loading. 3.2 Catalytic study For the synthesis of amide through the dehydrogenative coupling of amines with alcohol, the reaction was performed by taking 1 mmol of 4-nitro-benzyl alcohol (4-NO2-BA), 1 mmol of morpholine (MOP) in toluene (PhCH3) in presence of tBuOOH (100 μL) and 10 mg of the prepared catalyst under refluxing condition for 2 h at 40 °C. Under this condition the product yield was found to be 58%. Keeping all other conditions, the reaction was performed in different solvents to find a suitable solvent system. Therefore, the same reaction was conducted in solvents viz tetrahydrofuran (THF), acetonitrile (CH3CN), methanol (CH3OH), dimethylformamide (DMF), water (H2O). A moderate yield of 65% was found in CH3CN (Fig. 6 a). During the solvent optimization, we also monitored the time requirement, and it was found that 4 h of reaction time was sufficient to get the desired product. On optimizing oxidant amount 220 µL of tBuOOH gave 71% yield of product, the results are depicted in Fig. 6b. The reaction yield was monitored under varying temperatures from 20 °C to 80 °C and at 60 °C the maximum yield of 78% was obtained, Fig. 6c. On varying the catalyst amount from 10 to 30 mg, it was found that with 20 mg of catalyst amount the product yield improved to 83%, Fig. 6d. It is to be mentioned herein that the reaction was also conducted with two other oxidants, H2O2 and oxone but the success was very less so we preferred for tBuOOH. The reaction was unsuccessful with H2O2 and only 38% yield was obtained with oxone. On achieving the optimum reaction condition (20 mg of catalyst, CH3CN as solvent, 220 µL of tBuOOH, 4 h of time, 60 °C) different amides were synthesized. The isolated % yield and products of the synthesized amides (entry 1–18, product 3a-3r) are given in Table 1 . The synthesized compounds were characterized by 1H, 13C NMR, FTIR analysis and are provided in SI. It is pertinent to mention herein that certain anomalies occurred while doing dehydrogenative amide synthesis reaction with 2‑chloro-5-nitro benzyl alcohol (2-Cl-5-NO2-BA) and piperidine by following the above reaction condition, (entry 19–21, product 3s-3u), Table 1. With this disubstituted alcohol the corresponding amide was not obtained rather a good yield (∼80%) of 5-nitro-2-(piperidin-1-yl) benzaldehyde) was produced. After getting these results, the reaction conditions were re-optimized with this particular substrate. With all other parameters remaining constant the reaction required 100 µL of tBuOOH and was completed within 2 h giving ∼80% of isolated yield. For further confirmation, two other amines viz morpholine (2b) and imidazole (2e), were tested and obtained almost similar yield of 3t and 3u products, respectively, Table 1. Such changes were attributed to the -I effect of -NO2 that helped in the weakening of the CCl bond at the para position. The products were confirmed by 1H, 13C NMR spectroscopy and are provided in SI. It is pertinent to mention herein that in some of the NMR spectrum few unwanted signals were observed due to grease (δ=1–2 ppm) in n-hexane used as eluent during column chromatographic separation technique. No signal for any other biproduct was observed in the NMR as well as during the TLC analysis. The low % yield with some of the substrates was attributed to their low consumption during the catalytic reaction. To have an assurance about the formation The absence of by-product was confirmed from 1H and 13C NMR analysis of the reaction mixture performed with 4-NO2-Benzyl alcohol and morpholine. The NMR spectra of the reaction mixture provided in SI, Fig S9, S10 were composed of the signals charactertistics of the product and the reactant molecule confirming the absence of any other by-product. 3.2.1 Mechanism of the amide synthesis reaction The plausible mechanism of the reaction was believed to proceed through several steps. Initially, the addition of tBuOOH to the CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst probably lead to the formation of FeIV=O species. In this process the tBuOOH was supposed to get deprotonated by the basic sites of the zeolite-Y. The tBuOO − will co-ordinate to Fe(III) center by diffusing through the zeolite-Y pore-opening. The Fe-O-OBut so formed probably got stabilized within the cavity of zeolite-Y through confinement effect and non-covalent force of interaction. The rupturing of the Fe-O-O bond resulted in the formation of active site FeIV=O for benzyl alcohol (BA) oxidation, Step-I, Scheme 2 [56,57]. The deprotonated BA at the basic sites of the catalyst probably diffused to the active site located at the zeolite framework and thereby bound to the Fe(IV) sites, inset Scheme 2. At this step the activation of benzylic CH bond occurred and formed the benzaldehyde with the liberation of H2O as by-product. The selectivity of BA to benzaldehyde was controlled by zeolite-Y as they are known to provide better product selectivity [58]. Subsequently, the amine got inserted into the CuO surface through soft-soft interaction and do a nucleophilic attack at the aldehydic >C = O center as shown in step III and IV. Finally, the oxidation of amino(phenyl)methanol derivative to the desired amide occurred in presence of the catalyst and oxidant tBuOOH oxidation, i.e. step V. This step was assumed to be promoted by CuO species by shuttling its oxidation state in between +1 and +2 with the help of tBuOOH, as shown in step V[36]. A pictorial representation of the possible mechanism of amide formation is shown in Scheme 2. Lakshmi Kantam and co-workers proposed a free radical mechanism in presence CuO and tBuOOH for amide synthesis with DMF [35]. However, in our case the possibility of the free radical mechanism was not considered as the reaction did not proceed well giving almost the same % yield even in presence of a radical scavenging agent i.e. with TEMPO (2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidin-1-yl)oxyl). In order to support our reaction mechanism, Raman and cyclic voltammetry (CV) study was performed. From the Raman study it was found that after the addition of the oxidant the Raman signal at 668 cm−1 corresponding Fe-O stretching shifted to 693 cm−1 indicated for the interaction of the oxidant tBuOOH with the Fe site, Fig. 7 a. In presence of benzyl-alcohol, a new prominent signal appeared at 632 cm−1 for the Fe-O-C (phenolic) stretching frequency, Fig 7b [54,59]. This further validated our assumption for the formation of Fe-O-C bond as depicted in Scheme 1 (inset). In presence of both the substrate no any major change was observed apart from the small shifting of the CuO Raman signal from 300 to 291 cm−1, Fig. 7b. In addition there appeared a weak new signal at 355 cm−1 corresponding Cu-N bond formation, resulted from the interaction of the N-atom of amine (piperidine) with the active Cu-site in the catalyst, Fig. 7b [60]. The cyclic voltammogram of the catalyst showed one oxidation peak at +0.62 V and a reduction signal at −0.91 V for Fe(II)/Fe(III) couple, Fig. 8 a [61]. The CuO was found to be reluctant under the electrochemical condition. In presence of tBuOOH, apart from the other signals two new anodic signals were observed at +0.27 V and −0.91 V. The peak at +0.27 V was attributed to Cu(II)/Cu(I) couple that became active in presence of the oxidant, Fig. 8b [62]. The signal at +0.91 V was for the oxidation of Fe (III) species to Fe(IV) and was in accordance with our proposed mechanism [63, 64]. After addition of benzyl alcohol the Cu(II)/Cu(I) couple was retained at ∼ +0.3 V and a quasi reversible redox signal for Fe(III)/Fe(II) couple was found at −0.74 V and −0.66 V suggesting the interaction of Fe with the benzyl alcohol, Fig. 8b. A sharp rise in the current also indicated for the capability of the catalyst towards benzyl alcohol oxidation, Fig 8d. The above Raman and CV analysis thus provided the support to validate our proposed mechanism. 3.3 Comparative study with some of the reported catalysts In literature different synthetic techniques are available for amide bond formation [25–33]. But only a few results are available that account for the dehydrogenative alcohol and amine coupling [28,65-71]. Therefore, in Table 2 the comparison was made only with those literature results that used alcohol and amine as substrates. From the comparative study, it was evident that the % yield of the reaction was comparable with those of the catalysts of costly metals like Au, Pd, Ru along with some costly ligands [57-59,63]. Moreover, under our prevailing conditions, the reaction did not require any external base or reagents. The creation of strong basic sites at the catalyst surface served the purpose of the base. The time required for achieving the highest yield of 85% was also less in comparison to those of Ru, Au catalysts [66,68]. Under an identical condition our results were similar to that of Ag(I)-NHC catalyst entry 1, Table 2. The reactions performed with Fe and Cu catalyst used many costly reagents to do similar reaction, entry 5 and 6, Table 2 [69,70]. However, to the best of our knowledge, no such supported nanocatalyst of Cu and Fe are available in the literature that can do the direct amidation of benzyl alcohol with primary and secondary amines with good numbers of substrate scope. Therefore, the present approach can be beneficial in the synthesis of different types of amides with moderate to high yield. Although in terms of yield the prsent catalyst is not superior to the reported ones however there are many other adavantages associated with this catalyst − i) the metals (Cu and Fe) used in the catalyst were cheaper and their loading was comparatively very less than the most of the reported catalysts, that involves metals like Ag, Au, Pd. Currently the market price of Ag, Au, Pd and Ru are increasing at high rate while the metal like Fe is one of the most abundant element in the earth crust next to aluminum. Similarly, the Cu although considered as coinage metal but it market price is sufficiently less compared to of Au, Ag and Pd. Hence, if one can obtain almost similar activity like those resulted by the catalyst using such costly metal catalysts then the process will be cost effective and econimically viable ii) Secondly, the zeolite support can prevent the leaching of metals and can readsorbed the leached metals during filtration providing an easy approach for catalyst separation without destroying the integrity and overall stucture of the active metal species. iii) the temperature requirement was also comparatively less than many other reported catalysts entries 2, 3 and 8 of Table 2, iv) in addition to these the Cu-Fe hydrotalcite that was reported earlier by other researchers for similar type of reactions was also found to be less efficient than our present catalyst (describe in Section 3.4). Therefore, in summary we can say that although the yields were moderate to good, but the present catalyst have several other advantages in comparison to other catalysts. 3.4 Comparative catalytic study of CuO-Fe(III)-y with other Fe, Cu-based catalysts The catalytic activity of the amidation reaction was also performed with our previously synthesized CuONPs, iron-oxide (Fe2O3), CuO-Y (copper oxide supported on zeolite-Y), and Fe2O3-Y (iron oxide supported on zeolite-Y) and Fe2O3-HNT (iron oxide supported on halloysite nanotube) for comparison [19,54,57]. An unsupported copper-ferrite (CuFe2O4) was also synthesized using the reported procedure to understand the role of zeolite-Y [72]. The material was characterized by XRD analysis. The XRD pattern of CuFe2O4 nanoparticle resemble with the reported one and clearly shows the peaks in 2θ values at 30.04°(202), 35.84°(311), 44.03°(004), 54.03°(224), 57.25°(333), 62.1°(440) [73,74]. The detail of the synthetic procedure and XRD data provided in SI, (Fig. S2). The comparison was also done with the Cu-Fe hydrotalcite catalyst previously reported for the amidation of alcohol with formamide or DMF. The catalyst was synthesized as per the reported procedure by Lakshmikantam et al. [35] and was characterized by PXRD. The PXRD patterns resembled with the reported one and is provided in SI, Fig. S3. However, in the present condition the catalyst did not show any superior activity and the results are provide in Table S1. For the comparative study, the reaction of 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol and morpholine was considered under the optimized conditions. The results obtained with different Cu and Fe catalysts are given in Table S1. From the analysis, it was concluded that the synthesized CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst exhibited superior activity than the monometallic counterpart as well as the unsupported CuFe2O4 under the present optimized conditions, Table S1. The high activity with two metals system over the monometallic ones suggested that both Cu and Fe were essential for getting such activity. Further, the unsupported CuO and Fe2O3 did not give any product, Table S1. However, the zeolite-Y supported Cu and Fe catalyst resulted in some product formation with low % yield, Table S1. This clearly signified that zeolite-Y having both acidic and basic sites was essential for selective formation of amides. Moreover, the creation of stronger basic sites in the catalyst also helped in success of the reaction in absence of any external base. 3.5 Recyclability test To evaluate the recyclability of the material, the amide synthesis reaction between 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol and morpholine was considered under the optimized conditions. The recyclability test of the catalyst was done without any further treatment like Soxhlet extraction. The catalyst recovered after filtration was used directly for next cycle. The results depicted graphically in Fig. S3 showed that the catalyst was recyclable upto 6 cycles with minimum loss in catalytic activity. To know the reason behind the loss in activity, the amount of Cu and Fe content in the recycled catalyst was estimated from ICP-OES analysis. The ICP-OES analysis was performed on the recovered catalyst after the 2nd, 4th, 6th cycles. The results of ICP-OES analysis are provided in the SI, Table S2. From the ICP-OES analysis, the loss in metal content was not so significantly high that can lead to decrease in the productivity of the catalyst. In the catalytic run, upto 3rd cycle there was a very minimal difference in% yield (∼3%) with that of the fresh catalyst. Such loss was attributed to the error in extraction that was encountered during our repeated experiments, Table 1. Hence, the loss of metal content was not solely responsible for lowering the activity of the catalyst during the recyclability test. To have a better understanding about the catalyst activity, FTIR analysis was carried out to see any unreacted species remained bound to the catalyst surface. The FTIR spectrum recorded after 2nd cycle did not show any prominent signal corresponding to those of the reactants. So, the activity of the catalyst was well retained upto 4th cycle. However, the FTIR spectrum of the catalyst recorded after 4th and 6th cycle showed the characteristics signals for the substrate molecules as zeolite-Y do not show any IR frequencies in those regions (1200–1600 cm−1), Fig. S5. The FTIR analysis thus signified that during the recyclability test, a part of the reactant molecules remained bound to the catalyst surface and thereby blocked the active site of the catalyst resulting in the low product% yield. This probably happened because the catalyst was reused without any treatment or any other purification like Soxhlet extraction. The recycled catalyst was also characterized by PXRD, Raman, and TEM analysis, and are provided in SI, (Fig. S6). The PXRD of the recovered catalyst after the 6th cycle showed the disappearance of the peak for CuO indicating the leaching of CuO, Fig. S6a. The Raman signal was not well defined suggesting the change in the catalyst surface, Fig. S6b. The TEM image also clearly showed the significant destruction of the catalyst that led to a significant loss in the catalytic activity (Fig. S6c-d). Thus, from the above analysis it was concluded that leaching of metal ions, blocking of active sites by substrate deposition and loss in structural and surface morphology of the catalyst resulted in the deactivation of the catalyst ability after 4th cycle. The small loss in product yield during the initial three cycles was not due to such factors rather it was due to loss during extraction through column chromatographic separation. The recycling studies were also done in a kinetically controlled condition. The plot of % yield vs time in different cycles are depicted in SI, Fig. S7. In all the cycles the product yield was found to be maximum upto 4 h and after that, it became almost saturated. As there occurred small leaching during the recyclability test so to know the true heterogeneity nature of the catalyst, hot filtration test was also performed [75]. The hot filtration test was carried out by stopping the reaction after performing for 1.5 h and the catalyst was removed by filtration. On further performing the reaction with the remaining filtrate no any improvement in the % yield was observed and it became constant upto 5 h. The hot filtration test thus confirmed that the leached metals species were inefficient to catalyzed the reaction. The filtrate were also analysed by CV studies. The CVs of the filtrates recovered after 2nd, 4th, and 6th cycle are shown in Fig. S8. The CV of the filtrate recovered after 2nd cycle did not show any redox couple nor any signal for the BA oxidation. Similarly, in 4th cycle only a feeble peak was observed at +0.17 V but in the 6th cycle obtained weak peaks were observed at +0.58 V, −0.62 V and −0.65 V for Fe(II)/Fe(III) redox couple. The CV of the filtrates although showed peaks for leached metals but were completely different from those obtained during our mechanistic study, Fig. 8. This provided an evidence that the leached metal species were not involved in catalyzing the reaction. One of the advantage with zeolite-Y was that the leached metal can be readsorbed and the lost metals can be regained. The hot filtration test thus suggested that the even though few ppm amount of Cu or Fe content was present with the filtrate that was not sufficient to boost the reaction. Because the leached metal ions behaved independently in the solution state but for the reaction to happen the metals must act simultaneously. To further validate this fact, the reaction was tested with Cu(II) and Fe(III) salt but no results were found implying that conjugation between Cu and Fe was essential for the amidation of alcohol. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, it can be said that the synthesized supported CuO-nanocatalyst over Fe-exchange zeolite-Y appeared as a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst that can selectively dehydrogenate benzyl alcohols and consecutively coupled with amines to form the amides. The reaction was found to be highly selective without leading to the formation of any other minor product that can produce during the part of the reaction. The reaction conditions were much milder in comparison to other costly metal catalysts and the reaction happened without the need of any suitable ligand systems as well as under external base-free conditions. However, the selective formation of amides was found to be substrate selective. The 2‑chloro, 5-nitro benzyl alcohol substrate on reaction with different amines leads to CN bond coupling rather than the amide bond formation. coredata.dc:description: CuO nanocatalyst with layered structure was supported over Fe-exchanged zeolite-Y (CuO-Fe(III)-Y) for selective synthesis of amides by oxidative coupling of aromatic primary alcohols and amines. The CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst was characterized by different physicochemical and spectroscopic techniques. The amide bond formation reaction was found to occur in absence of any external base and reagents. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) study predicted the development of strong basic sites in the CuO-Fe(III)-Y catalyst that boosted the dehydrogenative coupling process. The activity of the material in such coupling reaction was found to be comparable to those of other costly metal catalysts under different reaction conditions. The product yield of the reaction was found to be substrate-dependent giving moderate to maximum yield of 85%. The anomalies in the reaction appeared in case of 5-nitro-2‑chloro-benzylalcohol that undergoes a CN coupling product through CCl bond activation. The mechanism of the reaction was believed to proceed through FeIV=O species that helped in the activation of the benzylic CH bond.
coredata.dc:title: CuO-Fe(III)-Zeolite-Y as efficient catalyst for oxidative alcohol-amine coupling reactions
